# Introduction

## Data

Quarto enables you to weave together content and executable code into a finished document. To learn more about Quarto see <https://quarto.org>.

```{r}
#| label: load-packages
#| echo: true
#| message: false

library(tidyverse)
library(ggthemes)
library(palmerpenguins)

glimpse(penguins)
```

## Plot

I would like to show you a simple boxplot.

```{r}
#| eval: true
#| label: fig-boxplot
#| fig-cap: "Boxplot: 1-100"

boxplot(1:100)
```

How about a scatterplot sample?

```{r}
#| eval: true
#| label: fig-scatterplot
#| fig-cap: "Scatterplot: 38 vehicles"
#| fig-width: 6
#| fig-height: 3

library(ggplot2)

ggplot(mpg, aes(x = hwy, y = cty, color = cyl)) + 
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5, size = 2) + 
  scale_color_viridis_c() + 
  theme_minimal()
```

Let us go through these two charts.

```{r}
#| eval: true
#| layout-ncol: 2
#| label: fig-bundle-charts
#| fig-cap: 
#|   - "Speed and Distance"
#|   - "Pressure and Temperature"

plot(cars)
plot(pressure)
```

How about changing the expression on the titles?

```{r}
#| eval: true
#| layout-ncol: 2
#| label: fig-bundle-charts-modified-0
#| fig-cap: "Bundle charts"
#| fig-subcap: 
#|   - "Speed and Distance"
#|   - "Pressure and Temperature"

plot(cars)
plot(pressure)
```

Looks better, huh? What if we wanna change a bit about the layout?

```{r}
#| eval: true
#| echo: fenced
#| layout: [[1],[1, 1]]
#| label: fig-bundle-charts-modified-1
#| fig-cap: "Bundle charts"
#| fig-subcap: 
#|   - "Speed and Distance"
#|   - "Pressure and Temperature"
#|   - "mtcars"

plot(cars)
plot(pressure)
plot(mtcars)
```

```{r}
#| eval: true
#| echo: fenced
#| layout: [[100],[30, 70]]
#| label: fig-bundle-charts-modified-2
#| fig-cap: "Bundle charts"
#| fig-subcap: 
#|   - "Speed and Distance"
#|   - "Pressure and Temperature"
#|   - "mtcars"

plot(cars)
plot(pressure)
plot(mtcars)
```

```{r}
#| eval: true
#| echo: fenced
#| layout: [[40, -20, 40],[100]]
#| label: fig-bundle-charts-modified-3
#| fig-cap: "Bundle charts"
#| fig-subcap: 
#|   - "Speed and Distance"
#|   - "Pressure and Temperature"
#|   - "mtcars"

plot(cars)
plot(pressure)
plot(mtcars)
```
